Review title: One of the best of all time
Review_body: Simply perfect in any way.The film addresses the story of three people who intertwine with each other, although it seems cliché Sergio Leone gives it in an unmatched way. The relationship that occurs between Blondie and Tuco is entirely natural, at no time is forced because one must be with the other, it is that humanism that there are between them two that is reflected throughout the trip, where with small actions It shows how well built the characters are, there is enough solidity in the lines and by God! Boy, no one demeans the characters, even the prostitute says consistent lines. The first scene of the bad is incredible, his great willingness to get what he wants is reasonable, he does not seek to dominate the world or defeat the good, only someone who has a goal in mind.The re-enactment of the war of succession is avant-garde, it shows both leaders that there are no good or bad, only people who die for something that has no logic, we can see how those generals who are not in the history books saw the war as a suffering, a pain, a destiny to fulfill where the only thing there is death.The film rejoices in the best photographs of the landscapes of Europe, the framing of the characters has the reason why it turns to the right, left, up or down, there is a reason and reason why go towards the character, because looking from afar, because take the horse's legs. The music is sublime, of the best songs in the history of cinema Ennio Morriconne is the only one who can compose for a confrontation in broad daylight and with Sergio Leone doing each take prolongs the sequence and still have that emotion about what will happen.The edition as well as the art design do not remain relegated to the wardrobe, you can see the great quality and commitment that is in every detail.Not to mention the performances, Eastwood, Wallach and Van Cleef manage to withdraw from themselves, forget who they are, that there is a camera in front and they do it like no one else can, they make art with their performances, of course Tuco does Laughing, as it changes from solemnity to sarcasm in a few seconds is worthy of applause. Angel Eyes manages to make a very organic antagonist, he does not need to scream, kill everyone, he knows when to shoot and at no time does he feel pretended. Bolndie is such an endearing character, even if he is from the old west you manage to feel his fear, his thirst, his kindness and his solidarity, and boy did he have to work hard to hold a rifle with his hands and they didn't shake.I could talk more about the film, to notice how it influenced many directors such as Tarantino, Scorsese, DePalma, Kurbick, Spielberg, Lucas, Fincher, Nolan until the Russo but I will let you see it yourself and note that a dialogue with many is not necessary lines, a stellar and choral cast, great special effects and the best sound, you just need to have an idea, love and passion for your work, let yourself be overwhelmed by the creativity of a soundtrack and show that with little you can do a lot and that you cannot it is the "what" but the "how".
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: After many years of barely watching any movies, I treated myself to several classics recently. And this was the best.That I so enjoyed this movie so much came as a shock to me. I literally never before have been able to even sit through a western, which (in my admittedly limited experience) was schlock action starring John Wayne as the taciturn all-American good guy being tough and beating up the outlaws. Watching GBU, I was enthralled for the entire three hours. Twice. And if I had time, I would have watched it a third time.The setting is typically western: a dry, dusty panorama in which men barely co-exist with each other; few wasted words; and lots of action, horses, and gunfighting in a wild west barely governed by incipient institutions of law & order - all shrouded within a morality play of good vs. bad. But what I liked so much is exactly what I hate about John Wayne westerns - the seriousness and honesty with which moral context is considered. In Hollywood, good vs. bad is as thoughtlessly superscripted as the protagonists' white and black hats. In GBU every remnant of moralizing has been ruthlessly cut.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Sergio Leone is the definition of artist and director. This movie is just the masterpiece of the art of cinema. The pictures, the dialogs, the actors, the location, the music, everything in that movie makes you feel that what you see is art. There is harmony, rhythm and especially there is realism in that film, something that's missing from the typical westerns. When i first saw that movie i felt like a car had run over me. Since then i still feel the same way when i see that film. Despite the large amount of films that i have seen since then this movie still remains the best film i have ever seen. I think Leone was a man with a very certain idea about cinema that personally finds me agreed. Of course that's just my opinion and i just want you to respect it.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This movie just take you back into a totally different world...20 out of 10 for soundtrack..Elli Wallach was outstanding in his character ... This movie has inspired Indian film like Sholay..

Review title: note on bad English dubbing for the DVD collector's set
Review_body: I've just seen this movie in it's complete form and I have mixed feelings about it. Here are the good points and bad points (no ugly points cause it's still a great picture and no pun intended.)The bad: The major problem with the English track is the additional dubbing for the new scenes; they stand out like sore thumb. Sure it's the voices of Eastwood and Wallach, but (the movie being forty years old)there voices have changed, Eastwood's voice has a lower pitch while wallach's is higher; I don't even want to go into Van Cleef's dubbing(he passed on so they brought in an impersonator to do his dialog). the dubbing quality for these new scenes are also not as good. I assume the original English dub was done in Italy. Even though the sync in audio and image was not perfect it's still one the best English dub tracks I've ever heard for motion picture. The Good: All hope is not lost however since MGM decided to include the original Italian mono track. Watching the film with this track makes the viewing experience a whole lot better.the restored scenes are better with this track as well since the Italian version was shown in its entirety when it opened in 1966. It does take some time to get used to watching it in this way (eg reading subtitles). Until we see a new edition that gives us a US and Italian cut of the film I would give this DVD marginal recommendation (or rent it just to see what it's like). The original DVD edition, with the cut US version, should still be for sale in some places so if you are a purist (or a nostalgic) you can still get that one at least.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Of course my favourite is Tuco Benedicto Pacifico Ramirez ("known as the rat"), he is my hero - a real "drifter" and as we say in danish "a luck-seeker"... Eli's performance is impressive and the way he and Blondie's "friendship" develop through the film is very memorable. The only thing that irritates me, i am sorry to say, is in the beginning when Blondie shoots peoples hats of.... thats seem a little foolish...Love it BIG TIME!

Review title: The good, the bad and the ugly
Review_body: Upon release of this movie the critics were not so mild with there comments, but this is in my opinion the best western ever made! Everything in this movie is well balanced. It shows how the west really was in my opinion. The director Sergio Leone takes his time to tell the story. He uses different types of camera angles, extreme close ups etc. This makes The Good The Bad And The Ugly a feast for your eyes! Also the actors are well casted. Eastwood plays his part with excellence as do the other two actors. Especially Eli Wallach is perfect in his role of Tuco. The music of Ennio Morricone is also the best! The openings-tune is known all over the world.It's a movie I can watch over and over again. And every time I do so, I discover new things.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: IntroductionNot so long ago Sergio Leone was only a cult figure. The Italian western was often thought to be a parody in itself, and Leone just happened to be the most skilful of those western making Italians. Today even people who are unfamiliar with the western genre know his name. He is considered by many as the greatest director of western movies in history, eclipsing even the names of a Ford or a Peckinpah. His movie The Good, the Bad and the Ugly is on top of most people's lists with favourite westerns, and Quentin Tarantino has called it the best directed movie of all time. The title has been referred to in fashion, construction, baseball, politics, pop music and God knows what more. Ennio Morricone's theme music has been used (and misused) so often, that it has become instantly recognisable to people of all ages in all corners of the world.# Looking for the UglyAccording to Dario Argento, who interviewed him at the time for an Italian newspaper, Sergio Leone had several films in mind after completing the second dollar movie, among them a biopic about Calamity Jane and Wild Bill Hickock (with Sophia Loren as Calamity Jane) a remake of Viva Villa! (a romanticized biopic of Pancho Villa), and an adventure movie set in war times. Some think The Good, the Bad and the Ugly originated in combining ideas for the remake and the adventure movie set in wartime. Leone wasn't really fascinated by the Mexican revolution (unlike some of his colleagues), nor in the historic figure of Pancho Villa, but had been impressed by Wallace Beery, who had portrayed the revolutionary as the typical, ebullient Latin character. He wanted to keep the character, but use it within a different context. The background for his movie, wouldn't be the Mexican Revolution, but the American Civil War, his main character not an altruist who was concerned with the destiny of his people, but a good-for-nothing who tried to survive in war time by using the hostilities to his own advantage.Leone's original choice for this 'ugly character' was Gian Maria Volonté, but he was afraid the character would become a neuropath when played by Volonté, and that was not what he had in mind. But then he saw Eli Wallach (some say in How the West was Won, others say in The Magnificent Seven) and all of a sudden he knew he had found the right actor: a dramatic actor with a natural talent for comedy, who reminded him of both Wallace Beery and Charlie Chaplin.The anchor pointThe Good, the Bad and the Ugly is the third and most ambitious part of Sergio Leone's so-called Dollar Trilogy, and also his third movie starring Clint Eastwood, the man who made himself a name by becoming the Man with No Name. Eastwood had been a cynical opportunist in A Fistful of Dollars and a bounty hunter in For a few a dollars More. In The Good, the Bad and the Ugly he's an opportunist again. In the triptych 'good-bad-ugly', he represents the good. But don't be fooled: like the opportunist and the bounty hunter from the previous two movies, the good is basically interested in money.In For a Few dollars More, No Name had appeared alongside a second protagonist, Colonel Mortimer, played by Lee Van Cleef, and the newcomer had stolen the movie away from the veteran. Now a third character was added, and again this newcomer would walk away with the movie. Eli Wallach's ambiguous character is the anchor point of the story, with two other characters, one good, one bad, contrasting with his 'ugly' nature. Neither of them was to be defined in traditional terms of morality. Blondie is only 'good' because he isn't as ugly as Tuco, and Tuco is only 'ugly' because he isn't as bad as Angel Eyes. But all three are rather merciless opportunists, ready to kill if necessary, and 'villains' in the traditional good/bad polarisation of the western movie. Leone wanted to demystify the adjectives, and at the same time show the absurdity of war. He was, in his own words, pursuing a theme Chaplin had exposed in Monsieur Verdoux, a study of a 20th century Bluebeard, operating on the eve of WW II, who confuses the people who have sentenced him to death with questions about the true meanings of good and bad.The PlotThe plot is relatively simple. Tuco, a Mexican outlaw, teams up with Blondie, an American bounty hunter. The American will turn the Mexican in, collect the reward money, but rescue him from hanging by shooting through the rope. As a couple of illusionists, they travel from town to town, repeating the same trick everywhere. Angel Eyes, on the other hand, is a hired gun who is looking for a Confederate soldier named Bill Carson, who knows of the whereabouts of a load of gold. The two stories intertwine when Tuco, who was double-crossed by Blondie, leads his former partner into the desert to kill him. They meet a moribund Bill Carson, who tells them about the gold, hidden on a cemetery: to Tuco he tells the name of the cemetery, to Blondie the name on the grave. The two dress up like Confederate soldiers, but they're captured by the Union and brought to a prison camp. Tuco has taken the identity of Bill Carson, and attracts the attention of Angel Eyes, who works in the camp as a sergeant. After a long series of incidents, with endless double-crossings and changing alliances, the three men arrive at the cemetery ...Ecstasy on the Altar of DeathThe Good, the Bad and the Ugly is an assured work, made by a film maker at the peak of his art. The movie has been called a comical nightmare as well as a study of the horrors of war. It is deeply rooted in the tradition of the picaresque novel and the commedia dell'arte, two Latin literary traditions. The picaresque story of three adventurers chasing the same treasure is punctuated by brief but poignant images of the war. We catch glimpses of executions, humiliations and torture, and it all culminates in this protracted scene of the trench war at Langstone Bridge. The cruelty of the war also defines the morality of the movie, and the characters involved in it. The three men can be real bastards, but the war is shown as an inferno of destruction and pain. Ironically the war also intervenes to save lives: a mysterious Confederate death wagon appears from nowhere when Tuco is about to kill Blondie, a mortar shell breaks the beam from which Blondie is about to be hanged, etc. This is the true absurdity of the war, and of life. Blowing up the bridge, basically a selfish act ("If those idiots stop fighting, we can cross the river"), also becomes an act of mercy: thanks to Blondie and Tuco the sympathetic Union officer, the 'philosopher' of the movie, can rest in peace. This idea of life by destruction, is mirrored in the famous 'ecstasy of gold' scene, with a greedy and ecstatic Tuco running in circles, looking for a name that can change his life in the midst of this altar of death, the cemetery called Sad Hill.ConclusionFunny, violent and meaningful, The Good, the Bad and the Ugly is probably as close to perfection as a film can get. A few jokes may be a bit insipid and I don't really like this shootout in a ghost town between Tuco and Blondie and Angel Eyes' men. There are also a few problems in regard to Angel Eyes' character: his appearance in a Northern POW camp is a bit suspicious (how did he get there, and how on earth did he become a sergeant in no time?). But some scenes, like the triello, the Mexican Standoff on the cemetery, and the ecstasy of gold, Tuco's run around the graves of Sad Hill, belong to the most beautiful ever filmed. The Langstone Bridge sequence is almost a movie within a movie. Morricone's score is one of the best of his impressive career. If you haven't seen this film yet, you have some work to do.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Great movie. The music, the scenery, the story. I have watched this movie many times. It is my all time favorite movie. Clint Eastwood is at his best. Eli Wallach plays a great role and often had me laughing. Lee Van Cleef is perfect for the part as the ugly, making you dislike him from the start. Three bounty hunters in search of the same treasure. The tension builds as the movie continues. I can actually feel the heat and the thirst in the desert scene. The close up photography is second to none. The movie is interesting from the beginning. It is a Civil War movie and a western all rolled into one. There is plenty of action. The music for the final gun battle keeps you on the edge of your seat. The ending catches you by surprise. I did not want this movie to end. The movie theme song is hard to top. You will find yourself whistling the first five notes over and over.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: The best western so far (we are talking 36 years). Clint Eastwood plays one of his best roles ever. He is the soft but tough guy from nowhere (as usual?). Use 3 hours and watch this western and you will use 6...9....12...hours. This is what western movies are all about.......
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Best western ever 10/10 one of the best threequels ever made.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: One of the best westerns of all time. Writing, acting and directing are all top notch.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: HDNet just broadcast "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" in High Definition. I haven't seen the film for many years and I was astounded.It is not apparently available on Blu-ray yet so try to catch it on HDNet. I hope they repeat it. The DVD cannot do it justice.In spite of historical inaccuracies, some preposterous scenarios and other plot weaknesses, brutal violence, some awful acting, and lip-sync problems with the Italian actors, it is a great film that engaged me completely for three hours.It is visually stunning with Leone's extreme close ups and its recreation of the time of the American Civil War. The protracted scenes (often whole stories in themselves) add to the visual poetry and to the evocation of the time.It is Leone's homage to the classic American Western. It relies heavily on the standard Western conventions but it is not constrained by them. Leone does it with his tongue planted firmly in his cheek. It should not be taken literally or even seriously and should be enjoyed for what it is.The characters are multidimensional. Eastwood's non-acting and Wallach's over the top performance add to rather than detract from the movie.It is possibly the most accurate portrayal of the American Civil War on film, showing it as the brutal and senseless conflict that it was.Its comments on greed, violence and human nature are poignant and yet the humor leavens the lessons.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: Music and footage - piece of art which haunts me to this day
Review_body: The Mexican Standoff or the part where the trio stare each other down with the music of Enrico and the spinning is very very cool and sets this movie apart from other Westerns. I still don't know why he Tucco calls him Blondie but that is the beauty - looks like brown to me. Also, when Tucco can't tell the difference between the Blue and Gray, and to his surprise along with Blondie's biting sarcasm, is priceless. Guess Eli can't see very well.... My son who is studying film at Yale believes this to be one of the better films for all other kinds of reasons...It is very much a black comedy and yet set the tone for other movies to feature anti-heroes. I recommend the entire trio along with Antonio Banderas as the El Marachi.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Watched this movie several times. Have good examples of charachter developing and balance in good movies. Enrio Marricone is great as always here. I guess i will rewatch it again too.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: There is so much that can be said about this film and is unforgettable performances....especially Eli Wallach as Tuco.  Has there ever been anyone better at saying nothing than Clint?  The ending is classic, and for those who haven't seen it, I won't ruin it, but it takes the classic gun fight to a new level..... not to mention the sound track, does it get any better....
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: I was neither a western film fan nor a long films fan. But this film really changed my view. Casting was excellently done without any doubt.Clint Eastwood is brilliant as the man with no name(Good,Blondie) with right personality and appearance for the character. Lee Van cleef too with his sharp eyes and evil look really does the justice for his villain character here. I think it is his best performance ever. But none tops the work of Eli Wallach as Tuco. I really liked him in a character like this than his character in Magnificent Seven. Other factor that makes this film so bright is that the stylish slow approach of the film in developing the story. I think Sergio Leone is a master craftsman there. Considering his great directing skills shown here I would give 10 out of 10 without a second thought.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: The king of one-liners, phenomenal soundtrack, and intense close ups of squinty eyes!
Review_body: This is the type of movie that has a lot of great one-liners. For example, "there are two types of people in this world, those with loaded guns and those that dig. You dig". This movie is full of lines like that, and when there are no lines there are intense staring scenes and close ups of people's eyes. Can't go wrong with a close up of those squinty Client Eastwood eyes! Interesting fact, Eastwood almost died during the filming of this movie, there is a scene where a bridge explodes and a piece of shrapnel flies within a meter of Eastwood. They left that scene in the movie, see for yourself.The soundtrack is phenomenal! I've been watching this movie since I was kid, when I did not even understand English, it was just as enjoyable.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: I could give 11 if I could !!!!!!!
Review_body: Yes that's right , it is one of the greatest action movies I 've ever seen.And it stands between the years and decades from it's realize ,as a classic cult movie , a legend of the Spaghetti Western era, or I should say "the Legend".I 've seen it about 5 times and I could watch it again. Sergio Leone has a cynic way to describe life in the Wild West ,between real people ,not just heroes who save their country from the Indians, but people who fight for their own lives. And also I must mention the composer Ennio Morricone whose brilliant music matches perfectly( like a piece of a puzzle ) in Leone's scenes and make the whole movie "A Great Piece Of Art".Old school though , but I would say that word again : - "Perfect!!" - "Cut!!"
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This is my first and thus far the best western movie I ever watched. Simple story, great screenplay, witty dialogues, everlasting theme music, wonderful acting.. make this western a masterpiece!Every time I watch this movie, my appreciation to cast and crew increases.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Maybe the best western movie ever. Sergio Leone and Ennio Morricone was the perfect combination. Their result was this magnificent movie. And of course only these actors could make the film much perfect. Clint Eastwood, Lee Van Cleef and Eli Wallach will remain in history. The best western movie ever!!!
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: There are three kinds of people in the world, my friend
Review_body: Without a doubt my all-time favorite western.The beginning of the film is so memorable, Eastwood = "The Good", Lee Van Cleef ="The Bad", and a Eli Wallach ="The Ugly". Actually the film is started from Some where, When Tuco said "There are two kinds of people in the world, my friend: Those with a rope around the neck, and the people who have the job of doing the cutting". The ending fight scene with its 3-way showdown is one of the most greatest pieces of film may be ever watched. Leone did his finest job with the camera direction in this movie and the acting is impressive. Eastwood, Van Cleef, and Wallach are absolutely fantastic.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: One of the greatest movies ever made!
Review_body: I remember when my Dad was able to find the DVD for GBU in 2002. So one day my Mom and Dad watched it, granted I was only ten at the time, I wasn't really interested. However I saw it last year with both of them and I realized that five years ago I chose late night Nickelodeon over one of the greatest films ever made! It truly didn't take more than two minutes to get me obsessed with the picture, and I had to watch it ten more times. It was a true classic! Every single scene in that picture is a definite classic, most particular the scenes where:1. Blondie helps and shares his cigar with the dying soldier, which was one of the most moving scenes ever.2. Tuco ends up at Sad Hill, and how he runs to find the grave marked "Arch Stanton". That whole scene is one of best in film history. 3. And obviously, the final Mexican standoff between Blondie, Tuco, and Angel Eyes. The score is simply amazing; whenever I see the standoff with the score reaching it's final crescendo, I get the chills every time. Who wouldn't? I mean, it doesn't matter how many times you've seen it.Rating: 10/10
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This film has it all, story, scenes, actors and amazing soundtrack.The Good, The Bad and The Ugly is a must see for any western fan. This is the last of Sergio Leone's films staring Mr Eastwood but this must be his greatest film. This was the first time I had heard music by Ennio Morricone, "Ectsasy of Gold" is highly recommended.The scenes are breathtaking (Trivia question, why are they called Spaghetti Westerns, answers on a postcard please) and the ending is not your typical shootout in the middle of a town... If not already please watch this film (uncut version if possible) and you'll see why its so highly rated on the IMDb top 250.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: I haven't commented on any movie before this but sometimes you watch a flick to just kill time and it completely changes your outlook towards movies.....the good the bad and the ugly is one such movie.....its the most expansive motion picture i've ever seen with performances to match especially those of eli wallach and eastwood....sergio leone's vision is unmatched till date and his eye for detail is a lesson to budding filmmakers....this is a movie you simply cannot miss not only for its intriguing story but also for the haunting background score which lingers throughout the movie and even after it.......i wish i could've seen it on the big screen to enjoy it even more..... to those who haven't seen it yet.....go ahead and enjoy!!!
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: What more can you say about this? It's regarded as one of the best westerns out there and I completely agree. It has interesting characters that you either love or love to hate.The story is a basic treasure hunt and while the concept is simple , it's very well made and has you on the edge of your seat for the whole time.While Clint Eastwood is well Clint Eastwood, Eli Wallach as Tuco and especially Lee Van Cleef as Angel Eyes stole the show for me. Amazing performances.The tension in this movie is so thick it even makes me sweat just by looking at it. And to top it off is the amazing as always score by Ennio Morricone.A must see for every western fan!
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This is my favorite film of all time.  This is a great journey - way more than just a western or an action film.  It captures the whole essence of the Civil War era Wild West.  There is enough plot to make 3 or 4 films.  I consider the graveyard standoff to be the best scene ever in a film.  What a classic!
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Simply genius movie, i wish they could do movies like this again*. Really a must watch for anyone not just hardcore western fans and but people who enjoys good film should watch this one. It is truly one of the great movies.Much to say about it but this is the short list: the acting, the action, the characters, the production values, and the originality.Clint Eastwood does a very good job in this movie but the real star is Lee Van Cleef, man he did a really good job.The score by Ennio Morricone's score is one of the very best ever committed to film, if you want to make a list of outstanding scores this has to be in top two.*(No Hollywood, for Heaven's sake no Reboot, Remake or stuff like that of this movie!)
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: What's so delightfully enduring about this epic adventure is that every single sequence is so endlessly entertaining and carefully choreographed. It's hard to pick a favorite scene, for every rewatch there's a different one. Of course, the film's climax with the immortal 'Ecstasy of Gold' and the unbearable suspense of the last standoff are its most celebrated moments, and the two-and-a-half-hour journey to get there could easily be a drag. Only, it isn't.The character introductions. Blondie and Tuco's chemistry and scheming. Angel Eyes' pursue for the cash box. A half-soldier. Tuco assembling his own gun. The desert sequence. Tuco and brother Ramirez. The POW camp. Digestive music. Wallace beating the crap out of Tuco. Blondie and Angel Eyes teaming up. Six men, six bullets. Bathtub scene. "When you have to shoot, shoot. Don't talk." The street shootout. The drunk Union Captain and the bridge. Sad Hill cemetery.Those are some of the treats this classic has to offer, and I think it makes it one of the most rewatchable movies ever made. But what else is there to enjoy?The soundtrack: Thinking of Sergio Leone is to think of Ennio Morricone, and this may be is magnum opus if you had to choose one. From the iconic whistling theme to the epic final standoff and the aforementioned 'The Ecstasy of Gold' (which if you've ever been to a Metallica concert, they always opens their shows with). But there are also the small bits between - trumpets, acoustic guitar and harmonica tunes breaths life to the backdrop that is the American Civil War (at least Leone's vision of it).The cinematography: Shot in Spain, posing as the American Southwest, Italian cinematographer Tonino Delli Colli fills every frame with gorgeous composition and gritty detail. There are so many iconic shots that are burned into cinema history and for this rewatch I finally got to enjoy it on Blu-ray in hi-def.Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo: As the title suggests, this story revolves around its characters. Lee Van Cleef as the villainous Angel Eyes is both cold and charismatic. Clint Eastwood as Blondie is the definition of cool. He always keeps his calm and doesn't speak unless he's got something badass to say. He also smokes cigar, has superhuman aim and he blows hats off people's heads. And there's Eli Wallach as Tuco - the unsung hero of this whole story. He's the shifty bandit you can't trust for a second. He's also got superhuman aim and I just love his swagger. He always makes me laugh, even when he's not talking, just his facial expressions cracks me up. He's also the character we get most backstory on, besides being the clown of the company, and you just can't help to feel sorry for him in the end. Perhaps my favorite character of all time. Those are the three mains which the story revolves around, but Leone had a talent for creating memorable minor roles as well - the alcoholic Union Captain in particular, who appears more than two hours into the film, heavily drunk and heavily dubbed, is downright hilarious.The charm: It's about America, made by Italians, shot mainly in Spain. Apart from the three American leads, most of the dialogue is dubbed, as the rest of the cast were either Italian or Spanish. But it doesn't mean the performances are bad or that it feels out of place - no, it just further enriches the everlasting charm of the spaghetti western and Leone's cinematic world. It's also a very unrealistic film - with comedically accurate gunslingers, revolvers sounding like cannons and the whole 'historical' setting. I've always regarded it as a borderline fantasy film, and I love it for it. It is plain and simple movie magic.Love it or hate it, 'The Good, the Bad and the Ugly' is undoubtably one of the most iconic films of all time and a big part of cinema history. For me, it's three hours of pure escapism and one of the most enduring adventures ever made for the big screen.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This is my favorite movie of all time. I'm not even a big fan of Westerns, either, but this movie somehow goes beyond that. Everything about this movie is amazing, the cameras, sound, some people might say it's too long, but the ending is great every time I watch it.Lee Van Cleef is an awesome bad guy too.. it doesn't get any better than that. Tuco is the ugliest of The Ugly, 100% immoral, a true criminal.. you just don't see many characters like that nowadays. Clint Eastwood hardly says a word, but still his best role ever, I think. This movie has been shown on TV, which completely ruins the whole point of it.. This is probably the only movie i will refuse to watch, unless it's widescreen & uncut. I love it that much
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: Cant believe that this film was made in the 60s!!!
Review_body: This is a true master piece from the legendary director Sergio Leone. one interesting thing about this film is that, its like wine, getting better and better after each year. personally i cant believe that film was made in the 60s. technique's used are brilliant. the characters shows a realism in their behavior, the good is not exactly good, explained by cheating ugly, or may be because he knows ugly too well. the characters are dressed like they just came out of a fashion magazine. the music is ever memorable. all the credits goes to Leone. i think he is the father of modern commercial film making, admired and followed by the great directors of today. his directorial style made spaghetti western to a genre from its meaning. we can see that in westerns made after this film. i have often wondered why this didn't get any Oscar or other major awards. after 40 years, its considered to be one of the best films ever made. its obvious from its rating in IMDb. the film that won Oscar in 66 was a man of all seasons. now where GBU is and that film is (am not trying to disparage 'man of all seasons'). GBU is been the inspiration of film makers all around the world and still lives in the heart of film makers. after seeing this film i became a fan of Leone and collected all his films, but still i believe this is his best work. some movies fade away from our memories but some would live in our memories for ever, this is the best of them...
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: The best most perfect movie there will be
Review_body: This movie is perfection... from the first frame to the fade out as Morricone's score plays it is art at its best. The score is beautiful. The sets are incredible. The story is engaging. The cinematography is magnificent. The performances are incredible. All the characters are so simple, the audience make them complex by adding their own backgrounds/concepts to Angel Eyes, Tuco and Blondie. Eli Whallac steals the movie! In reality the movie is about Tuco, not about the villain or the good guy, this makes the movie feel fresh and unpredictable which adds to the amazing nerve wrecking climax.This movie has been an inspiration to me. Sergio Leone is amazing! He directs with his soul.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: Words cannot describe the enormity of this film.
Review_body: There are certain things in life that are unexplainable and incomprehensible in their magnitude. These exalted anomalies include - in no particular order - Revolver, Guernica, The Sistine Chapel, The Ninth Symphony, The Waste Land, Macbeth and then there is this.This movie expresses a gamut of emotions; every new scene shows a side of a character that one thought was unimaginable; the acting is nothing less than breathtaking and the use of sound and music is unprecedented.I don't often make bold, sweeping statements, but here goes: this movie could not have been made any better in any regard possible.Tarantino was quoted as saying that this movie is the best directed movie of all time; who am I to disagree with him? 10/10 without a shadow of a doubt.P.S. I would have given it ten even if it were based on the Standoff alone.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: So may attempts, but none is better than this.
Review_body: I don't think there's any better western movie than this. The epic, magnificent ending for the Dollars trilogy by Sergio Leone is also the best film. You can find everything you can expect from a western movie: gun challenges, tricks, frauds, deserts, the hunt for treasure, bandits, all brilliantly directed by Leone. Action, irony, thrilling. Clint Eastwood is, as always, perfect as the "man with no name": mysterious, no past, no emotions, the only thing we know is that he wants money. Lee van Cleef is also great for his "bad guy" role, it fits him so very well that now I can't imagine him in a different role than Angel Eyes. But the best of the three is maybe Eli Wallach: his acting performance is simply impressive. This film gave us so many famous phrases that we keep using them even now. The scenes have a perfect synchronicity. And the music is a masterpiece by Ennio Morricone. If you want to make a culture about western movies, be sure to watch "The good, the bad, the ugly" for last, or else it would spoil the fun for the other movies.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: The best movie of all time
Review_body: This movie is simply put, the best movie of all time. Everything about this movie was perfect. The direction, the score, the setting, the acting, everything. The characters are developed and are definitely memorable. This movie has it all, humor, action, adventure, drama, and definitely the greatest ending to a movie in the history of film. The plot of the story is definitely more than a simple hunt for treasure, morals are spread through out the film symbolically and explicitly.Sergio Leone's visionary, direction style is shown once again, and I can go on and on and on about it, but then i'd be writing for days upon days.Tuco, blondie, and Sentenza/Angel Eyes. Three of the most iconic, and memorable characters ever. Tuco displays the "ugly" side of people. Tuco is selfish, apathetic, a liar, a cheater, often two faced and down right dirty. Sentenza/Angel eyes is a cold hearted, sociopathic, bounty hunter, who does whatever it takes to get his job done. Blondie is not the typical good guy. He is amoral, greedy, and holds many of the characteristics as Tuco and Angel eyes. He is not the same type of good guy that John Wayne portrays, Blondie portrays a more realistic form of what a "good guy" would be in the west. Greed, dishonesty, and selfishness are traits we all have. Blondie however is the epitome of masculinity, with his poncho wearing, cigar smoking, quick with the pistol ways, and I cant help but admire him. What especially stands out about these characters is how they are able to accurately display human nature. Critics deem these characters as amoral, but everyone who exists on the planet is amoral in a certain sense. Sergio leone, and his great cast capture this reality in this epic adventure."$200,000 is a lot of money, we're gonna have to earn it." That line is definitely one of the greatest lines in the movie, as well as one of the most masculine. The final scenes from Tuco's ecstasy of the treasure to the Mexican standoff (which is one of the most creative and unexpected end to an epic western)left me in awe, along with ennio morricones ultimate score. People argue that this movie is just about a greedy treasure hunt, and can't live up to something as captivating as a revenge story, like once upon a time in the west. First of all it is not just a greedy treasure hunt, as i said before it is a trip into human nature, adventure and masculinity. Secondly, what it comes down to is your taste in movies. If you're a more masculine, adventurous person, you'll admire the good the bad and the ugly, but if your into revenge, and honor then once upon a time in the west is your movie. You can learn a lot about people by the movies they enjoy.Its just a shame that people today cannot enjoy this fantastic movie. Im 16 years old and every time i try to show my friends they always shoot it down, or end up not understanding it. It is a terrible shame how movie making has turned from an art to just a quick get rich scheme.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Good, yes, but imo not at the level that most reviewers seem to have put it.As ever, Sergio Leone has created a bit of a masterpiece greatly enhanced by the music of Morricone. The music and film play in the final graveyard scene probably stand shoulder to shoulder with anything else produced in film history.The main minuses: Good, Bad and Ugly does not accurately describe the main characters. None were good, and Tuco imo was easily the most bad. Probably should not make too much of this, but it makes the title deceptive.The film is too long. Whilst the storyline is sprawling, some scenes could have been cut back timewise and maybe even omitted.I found Tuco annoying, and it was out of character for Monco to let him live.I preferred For a Few Dollars More in the trilogy, and certainly think Once Upon a Time in the West is far superior.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: Loosely following the trail of three outlaws looking for Civil War loot buried in a grave. I like the commingling of the treasure plot and the hell of war. The battle scenes showed the carnage of brothers fighting brothers, often over nothing more than who controls a bridge...Deep and sometimes shallow...
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: The Best Western movie. And the best acting crew.
Review_body: This is the my first western movie I have ever seen. This is also my first Clint Eastwood movie. It created such an impact on me that I started comparing every western movie with it. I did not watch any John Wayne movie. But for me Clint is the best Western actor for ever. After this movie I collected remaining of his Westerns and watched. I have watched nine of his Westerns. Every one of them is good. Then I could not stop of watching his other genres. skills. He just acts what the character needs in particular frame, not more than that nor less than that. I think this is the reason he did not get the Oscar even he nominated. Now he is proving his directions kills. The background music in this is a trademark. Many of our Indian directors still use this music as reference or directly into movies. I think Sergio Leone is one of the top directors from Italy.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: The single greatest movie ever made.
Review_body: I don't know what happened on imdb, but when I joined, this was the #3 ranked movie of all-time. Which is too low. It was only behind Godfather 1 & 2, and this makes them seem like a soap opera compared to a Best Picture Oscar nominee. Speaking of which, this is the best movie ever made to have never recieved a single oscar nomination. Nowadays, Clint Eastwood would've gotten Best Actor. Eli Wallach would've gotten Best Supporting Actor. Lee Van Cleef would've gotten a Best Supporting Actor nomination. Sergio Leone, Best Director. Screenplay, cinematography, musical score, the list goes on. It's not only the definitive western, but it has several other elements and plot lines. It's also a drama, a suspense film, a war film, an action flick, and a treasure hunt movie. With no details, it also has the greatest ending to a film ever put on screen. But everything about this movie is what makes it an all-time classic. Especially the reason it could never be successfully remade. The acting, screenwriting, directing, camera work, and brilliant musical score by Ennio Morricone are what make it unique to the point it can never be duplicated or improved. It isn't my favorite movie, but I tell everyone and anyone that this is the best movie ever made. I only believe that because everything in the movie holds its own and backs it up, and I hope anyone who watches it believes the same.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: If you never watched this film because you thought it looked boring...
Review_body: Then, respectively, You Sir or Madam are a fool. Badly dubbed, sillily cast and horribly underloved, this is possibly the greatest caper of its time and ever since. In a time of Hollywood heroes, horrifying villains and not many people in between, Leone submits one of his many masterpieces to exhibition, at a time when America had given up on the western because it had nowhere else to go. This film offers no heroes, gives you a villain and places a slimy little dog like tuco into the midst of the most realistic portrayal of the west the way it was. Sad, lonely and most certainly devoid of John Ford colour. Ironic really that one of the most loved westerns of all time was made in Europe. Good job really, though. The Americans never could get their history right. Clint has never been so squinty, Wallach so perfectly cast and Leone so frankly plain. Film fans, this is a must see. But if you are a casual viewer you may want to steer clear, for only a tide of angry rebuttal awaits your confusion and refutation on the web.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This movie is truly a masterpiece in ever sense of the word, with regards to the cinema arts. The sound, the music, the editing, the context of the movie within the trilogy. The actors, the perfect use of timing and building the suspense and still leave just enough undetermined, but still giving the viewer enough satisfaction. I went into the movie knowing it was pretty amazing, but just truly didn't grasp just how amazing it would be. Yes, its a bit slow for modern times and there is very little talking, but if you go into the movie with the context of when it was made, along with the context and understanding of how other movies in this time frame and genre, you will find that this movie truly is the pinnacle in not just western films, but in all cinematic movies in general. This movie is truly worth the time, and I do think you should try to watch the movies that came before it in the trilogy, before watching this one. Overall an A+ movie.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: Leone was a precursor of the comedy action movies that today are the recipe of the MCU success
Review_body: The film The Good, the Bad and the Ugly is the greatest exponent of the spaghetti western and for some it could even be the best film of all time in this genre. The three-dimensionality of the characters in the film is unmatched. Fifty years before the MCU, Sergio Leone laid the foundation for epic action films that successfully amalgamate comedy in an organic way and feature antiheroes capable of connecting with the audience in a natural way, as we see him more frequently today in movies of James Gunn or Taika Waititi.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: This Movie is the Best Western movie until now. The direction was awesome! All actors perform exquisitely. Specially Eli Wallach. In these opening frames, Sergio Leone established a rule that he follows throughout "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." The rule is that the ability to see is limited by the sides of the frame. At important moments in the film, what the camera cannot see, the characters cannot see, and that gives Leone the freedom to surprise us with entrances that cannot be explained by the practical geography of his shots.There is a moment, for example, when men do not notice a vast encampment of the Union Army until they stumble upon it. And a moment in a cemetery when a man materializes out of thin air even though he should have been visible for a mile. And the way men walk down a street in full view and nobody is able to shoot them, maybe because they are not in the same frame with them.Leone cares not at all about the practical or the plausible, and builds his great film on the rubbish of Western movie clichés, using style to elevate dreck into art. When the movie opened in America in late 1967, not long after its predecessors "A Fistful of Dollars" (1964) and "For a Few Dollars More" (1965), audiences knew they liked it, but did they know why?I saw it sitting in the front row of the balcony of the Oriental Theatre, whose vast wide screen was ideal for Leone's operatic compositions. I responded strongly, but had been a movie critic less than a year, and did not always have the wisdom to value instinct over prudence. Looking up my old review, I see I described a four-star movie but only gave it three stars, perhaps because it was a "spaghetti Western" and so could not be art.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: I first watched this movie about 20 years ago with my father. Father and son and sometimes mother, we'd watch Western movies and laugh and cry, but this movie stands throughout all of the fond memories as my favorite. It has it all. The good, the bad, AND the ugly and so many more in the in- between areas. I love it.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: A vast empty Western landscape. The camera pans across it. Then the shot slides onto a sunburned, desperate face. The long shot has become a closeup without a cut, revealing that the landscape was not empty but occupied by a desperado very close to us.In these opening frames, Sergio Leone established a rule that he follows throughout "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." The rule is that the ability to see is limited by the sides of the frame. At important moments in the film, what the camera cannot see, the characters cannot see, and that gives Leone the freedom to surprise us with entrances that cannot be explained by the practical geography of his shots.There is a moment, for example, when men do not notice a vast encampment of the Union Army until they stumble upon it. And a moment in a cemetery when a man materializes out of thin air even though he should have been visible for a mile. And the way men walk down a street in full view and nobody is able to shoot them, maybe because they are not in the same frame with them.Leone cares not at all about the practical or the plausible, and builds his great film on the rubbish of Western movie clichés, using style to elevate dreck into art. When the movie opened in America in late 1967, not long after its predecessors "A Fistful of Dollars" (1964) and "For a Few Dollars More" (1965), audiences knew they liked it, but did they know why?I saw it sitting in the front row of the balcony of the Oriental Theatre, whose vast wide screen was ideal for Leone's operatic compositions. I responded strongly, but had been a movie critic less than a year, and did not always have the wisdom to value instinct over prudence. Looking up my old review, I see I described a four-star movie but only gave it three stars, perhaps because it was a "spaghetti Western" and so could not be art.But art it is, summoned out of the imagination of Leone and painted on the wide screen so vividly that we forget what marginal productions these films were--that Clint Eastwood was a Hollywood reject, that budgetary restraints ($200,000 for "Fistful") caused gaping continuity errors, that there wasn't a lot of dialogue because it was easier to shoot silent and fill the soundtrack with music and effects. There was even a pathetic attempt to make the films seem more American; I learn from the critic Glenn Erickson that Leone was credited as "Bob Robertson" in the early prints of "Fistful," and composer Ennio Morricone, whose lonely, mournful scores are inseparable from the films, was "Dan Savio." Even Eastwood's character, the famous Man With No Name, was an invention of the publicists; he was called Joe in the first movie, Manco in the second, and Blondie in the third.HALF REVIEW BY ----- Roger Ebert
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: When you know every line and every action and every note of the score, THAT'S a film you love.Eli was one of the few actors that I longed to meet. His work from "A Cold Night's Death", to "The Deep", to an episode of my favorite TV series Kojak, Eli was always the consummate professional. Age was never a factor in his career.Clint Eastwood even had a place for him in "Mystic River."And his sense of timing and improvisation was second to none.I miss him terribly and encourage all aspiring actors to watch his work and view his moments that move me deeply.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review_body: I saw this movie on Amazon Instant Video. This movie is excellent and its story has a lot of ups and downs, the movie also has the famous western movie star Clint Eastwood. So I was mesmerized by the movie and recommend others to appreciate it.The movie has three leading roles which has different characters. The good person is called Blondie. The bad person is called Angel Eyes. The ugly person is called Tuco. The story happened during American Civil War, and developed gradually among the three western cowboys.Along with the story developing, a man tells the ugly man that there has a huge government wealth worth $200,000. The man tells the region of secret wealth, and the region named Sad Hill Cemetery has thousands of graves. However, the man does not tell the ugly man what the name of the grave which conceals the wealth, but tells the good man. Thus, the good man and the ugly decide to find the wealth jointly. Meanwhile, the bad man who disguises as a Union soldier also begins to find the huge wealth, and the three people meet in battle coincidentally. Then, they against each other by fist and gun fight intensely. Finally, after a lot of fights, the good man and the ugly man find the way to Sad Hill Cemetery.However, the way is blocked by the war between Union and Confederate, and the two forces fight constantly in order to occupy a bridge. Finally, the good man and the ugly man destroy the bridge by bombs. In the end, the bad man arrives in the region of secret wealth at the same time. The three cowboys decide to gun duel and the winner can get the wealth. Finally, the good man kills the bad man in the duel and releases the ugly man. The good man separate the wealth with the ugly man, and the good man leaves the ugly man in the desert. The final scene is that the good man rides his horse and disappears in the distance.The movie uses third person view to describe the fantastic story. The story depicts three different people deeply. They have different dispositions and distinguish each other brightly. The movie has a strong western atmosphere. For example, the whole story develops in the desert, and this is the typical character of the west of America. The three people have classic cowboy's appearance and trait. They have cowboy wear, especially the classic hat. They have a cool handgun and good gun skill. So they can hit a thin rope from a long distance. They judge other people with narrow eyes.This movie is different with former western movies. People do not divide to good or bad clearly. There is no a totally good person or a totally bad person. The good man also wants to gain the wealth and more money by fighting with others. The ugly man can be touched by some sorrowful things and help others by his own way. All people have two sides, good and bad. This idea in the movie causes big change in future western stories and movies. This movie also uses huge scenes to describe the most destructive of wars. Hundred thousand people die in the war and their bodies fall apart on the desert. This is a big satire of three people shuttle between two armies just in order to find the secret wealth. The movie also uses fierce gun fight to make the story ups and downs. For example, in the end, three people duel each other. They stare each other last 5 minutes and no one open the fire without careful thought. This scene makes audiences feel nervous and exciting.Personally, The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly is a very legendary movie and shakes me a lot. Thus, I saw the movie 3 times and think it is very wonderful. This movie not only is a lot of intense gun fight, but also reflects people's inner thoughts vividly. The three people have the same purpose but have different characters, so there are a lot of conflicts in the story. In the whole story, many scenes impress me a lot. For example, a command of Union is wounded in the war and will die soon. After the good man and the ugly man destroy the bridge between two armies, the command smiles and dies in happy. This sorrowful fragment reveals that people do not want to battle in war and they want to pursue peace. Another scene is that before the good man and the ugly man arrive in the destination, the good man meets a nearly dead soldier of Confederate. The good man puts his clothes on the soldier's body and gives his cigar to the soldier. The soldier smokes the final cigar and dies. This story tells us how the cruel is in the war.The movie also reflects the spirit of the Wild West. Like in the course book, the three cowboys are strong and do things without the law. They kill people cold and unconcerned. They are individual in most of time and there is no woman to accomplish them. They solve problems by dangerous fight or duel and do things what they want to. They are uncontrolled and use unscrupulous divisive tactics. They pursue the material wealth and have can-do spirit.I love this movie is also because of its wonderful music. In intense gun fight, the music is strong and curse. In sorrowful environment, the music is slow and emotionally. Especially before the end of movie, the ugly man run between thousands of graves to find the right name of the grave which conceals the wealth. The music describe the situation coordinately and becomes classic until today.You cannot miss this excellent movie, despite the language in the movie is Italian, but this does not block you to understand the story.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: An excellent tribute to the spaghetti western
Review_body: This is easily the best of the dollars trilogy and one of Sergio Leone's finest works in cinematography during this era. The plot is captivating and the quality of the film is very good even for a film dated back in a year when England won its only World Cup. It's hard to believe that so much has changed since then but yet this classic gem is a shining reminder of an age of westerns that has yet to see its like again. I don't even think "django unchained" could successfully mimic a milestone of this caliber as much as it tried. This is the genuine cinematic treasure for western fans from all walks of life. The cast is loaded with classic stars like Lee Van Cleef and the legend himself, Clint Eastwood, and it's worth its value for the price you pay when purchasing the restored DVD with all of the extras, this is one film any western fan wouldn't want to miss in their collection.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: One Of The Most Intitally Underrated Movies
Review_body: Upon its' release in the United States, The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly, was marred by film critics and their reviews of the film. I believe the Wikipedia page on the film, if you would like proof of its reception when it was released, it is under Contemporaneous reception. But since it's' release and contemporaneous reception, several well-known film critics like the great Rodger Ebert, have given it the rating it deserved and recognition as the film we know and love. I had known about it for a while and never watched it until my father showed it to me back in 2009. I will never forget watching with my dad and then learning how all great classic films are meant to be watched, with the people that you love. That next day my father passed away suddenly, but the memory of watching this movie lives on. From now until I die, I will cherish The Good, the Bad and the Ugly for all that is!
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: In this review, I discuss the film's music.
Review_body: The Effects of the Music in the Film The Good the Bad and the Ugly by Brian CoatneyThe Good the Bad and the Ugly made its indelible imprint in 1966 as the third of the Spaghetti Western trilogy, and it remains a piece of cultural lore even today for its inimitable synchronization of music and acting that produce dramatic tension neither the music or acting alone could generate. With a script that violently veers from traditional Western themes, Sergio Leone's artistic classic changed American culture as much as Woodstock did. Only a book could detail all the interesting aspects of the film, but here, I will comment on the music. Music is universal and sometimes music strikes us in a way we're not even conscious of, and it draws us with a power and mystique we can't yet identify and probably don't give that much thought to at first. Don't we often respond first by liking or disliking something before we know how to analyze why? So it was with the music in the Good the Bad and the Ugly. All I knew was that the music created an alluring mood in a mysterious and enticing way, giving the sense of what film critic Bill Warren calls an "astonishing score." The music is, in fact, exceedingly more than mere background or accompaniment to the film's action; its "lonely, mournful scores are inseparable from the film" (Ebert). Critic Vince Leo says that Morricone's score enabled the film to go from "good film to masterpiece." Not only that, "Unlike most films, where the composer would create the music based on what happens on the screen, it is said that Leone worked the opposite way, constructing scenes to fit the pieces of music" (Leo). One might say that with The Good the Bad and the Ugly, we enjoy a film made for its soundtrack rather than a soundtrack made for a film. If asked to describe the music of the film without reference to research, I would have described it like this: full of melody, a whistle pipe sound, rattle snake clicking at times, escalating tension on some kind of stringed instrument, slightly orchestral sounds, choral–like chanting voices, dramatic and paced buildup of tension—all of which was not overpowered with bass, rhythm, and vocals, meaning therefore not a band trying to create a full sound at high amperage. Somehow the music linked to the action, or shall I say non-action; for the music came into presence most it seemed when the characters stopped, spoke little, and hovered on the verge of a new twist in the drama: someone was about to draw, see an ominous presence, or experience an encounter of deep pathos and random violence—violence random to the victim but part of the consuming scheme of getting the gold buried in the graveyard somewhere. The famous signature score for the film came to signify in popular culture, a dramatic moment with peril in the air, a kind of pop icon score tied to antiheroes and subjugation of one person's dreams to those of another. A look at the critics fills in the detail that clarifies exactly what Morricone did. Max Garrone calls the film "balletic violence," with its "grand arias of whoops, whistles, Jew's-harps, gunshots and other errata." Also, we learn that the sound comes from a "blend of guitars, drums, and hyena-like cries from the singers" (Leo). Getting more precise, Warren points out that Morrricone, "blends elements of Mexican mariachi music with contemporary jazz, sweeping orchestral passages, choral voices, and an overall vividly distinctive approach." The music so much penetrates the film that it "incorporates the howl of a coyote—the first thing we hear in the movie itself—into the themes he creates for each title character, though the wail is orchestrated very differently each time" (Warren). Director, Serge Leone, then must mean for us to hear the coyote's pathos in each character, whether good, bad, or ugly—a wail that gives us the prime musical elixir that penetrates and binds together the film's tone of deep pathos. Works CitedEbert, Roger. "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly." Rogerebert.com. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.Garrone, Max. "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly." Salon.com. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.Leo, Vince."The Good, The Bad and the Ugly (1966) / Western-Action aka Il Buono, Il Bruto, Il Cattivo." Quipster's Movie Reviews. Web. 14 Feb. 2008.Warren, Bill. DVD Reviews. Review_body: Hi, all you commentators !It's great to know that there are many many people around the world who look at this film as I do, -Numero Uno.Since my last Comment (June 2003), I have now got the full Directors cut, complete with the deleted scenes back in. At the time, I commented that it should be technically fairly easy to "splice" these back in and have people to voice over the original Italian dialogue.But then hey, what happens, ! They've gone and done the best possible thing, hired Clint Eastwood and Eli Wallach to voice over their own original dialogue (plus another to double on Lee Van Cleef)- Almost forty years later !.This totally revamped film with its replaced scenes makes it a whole new thrill to watch. If you haven't got it, then get it pronto!I have no doubt that with the passage of time, The Good, The Bad and the Ugly will become certainly the greatest western ever made and possibly one of the top films of all time.See you soon, idiots !
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: The reason why I started working in film.
Review_body: I don't want to lose too many words to this movie, as it speaks for itself. Although being one of the most influential and important Western films of all time, I have a very special connection to this film.Back when I was a child of 10 years, "The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly" was one of the first rated movie my father ever showed to me - although not being anywhere near the advised age. It didn't matter anyway, as I was deeply touched by the movie back then. It was its visuals, the incredibly well shaped characters (main and support) and the unforgettable and everlasting mega-score of the old master, Ennio Morricone. Grown up to a father, both Italian and a producer, film and especially Italian film was always a topic and a passion that made up a huge part in our family life. Still, I've never seen my father more emotional and feverishly romanticising about a movie as he did it with that one.Nowadays, having seen this beauty for so many times that I lost count, I honestly recognise something new with every new session. It doesn't really matter if you focus on the unbeliveably well visualised portrayal of social contrasts in the past US, or the break with the glorification of classical American Western movies - this film was and still is revolutionary for its time and a predecessor for all the great Western, and other films in other genres, you can watch and enjoy today.I fell in love with this movie when I was 10 and I still get the same feeling every time I rewatch this beauty.10 out of 10 (and not just because of the age...)
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: From the look of Eastwood, to the music, humour and moral ambiguity, this is amazing ground breaking cinema as art.
Review_body: I recently saw this movie for the first time at an outdoor cinema on the big screen, and was absolutely blown away.  I loved the way the story was developed slowly, the fact that hardly a word was said for the first 5-10 minutes.  I don't think I've ever seen a movie where the music and the pace of the movie work so well together, almost as one, and it helps build the story and create an amazing atmosphere. Clint Eastwood look absolutely beautiful, he is a stunning man to look at on screen, his character has some real complexity and rough edges.I loved the sense of humour and the moral ambiguity. The way the movie was shot and especially the final scene at the graveyard with the close ups, genuinely pulled me into the tension of the story to a point where I totally forgot about all the followers that have used this technique and turned it into a cliche.The actually story itself, with the three characters, was complex and showed depth.  So the storyline, cinematography, development of plot, combination of music and movie make for an absolutely riveting film.
Movie_name: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

Review title: One of my favorite movies of all time

The acting, pretense,writing,and action is amazing. I love Clint Eastwood so much and this is by far my favorite movie of his. I normally hate all western but this is one of the only western movies I've ever liked. It definitely deserves its very high reviews and I don't expect them to go down any time soon. Review title: This was an interesting and exciting movie that tells an interesting story.

When it did it started with action which you don't see very often in movies. For a movie made in 1966 it was really good except for the sound was off a little and they would say something and there lips were talking before the sound of there voice came on, but after about a half hour in I didn't notice it. In the summary I said that it told a good story because the story filliped around a few times, I think that is why I liked the movie so much. This movie does not get boring if you watch it over a couple of times ether. Over all the movie was interesting and Clint Eastwood played his part really well.

Review_body: I have watched this movie many times and always take my breath away.The Good, The bad and the Ugly is the best western ever made. Sergio Leone as director, it cant go wrong. I also like the two other movies from the Dollar trilogy but this movie of course take the price.
